tweets.text: Taking up @vgr challenge on  being a design professional. I haven't enough followers to get to 100, but here's a few to get things started...

1. Some people dont respect design. It's like drawing, only simpler & more easy, and they cld do that logo, website, banner ad or poster (and will) if they want to in lieu of paying someone else to do it.

Design schools want your money, and if that means graduating your talentless son or daughter, friend, brother, sister, or yourself, they will. No physical harm can come by it. If you dedicate yourself and show up for class, you'll graduate, but you still wont have talent.

3. If you get into a design school & a teacher tells you you have no talent, be grateful (after accepting a harsh truth) tht they were honest w you (& tht it wasnt a creative director years after paying school loan debt at 6-12% interest, to hone skills you simply do not possess)
4. Being a good designer doesn't *require* knowing how to draw, but knowing how to draw comes w many other talents that transcend being good at design and are *almost always* concurrent.
5. If you have an eye for good design but lack the skills to apply it to your own work you can still make it by finding great designers to follow and steal from.
6. If you dont know how to properly steal, you will not make it.

7. Some left-brained C-level ppl who are good at saving your design agency money will offer their opinions on your designs (bc anyone can do it--see 1.). They shouldn't, and as a good designer you should (respectfully) ignore them.

8. Some C-level ppl who are good at saving your design agency money will go a step further and suggest what (insert here) design shld look like, and campaign against you for not listening to them the first time. 

Start sending out CSVs.
9. Always have your CSV or resume up-to-date. Always keep a cache of your latest (and best) stuff to showcase.

10. You just graduated. Youve got some great student pieces & few freelance projects to show your 1st potential full-time employer. Never, ever show them everything. Not everything is worth showing. Widdle it down & only show your strongest stuff, even if it's just 5 ttl examples

11. If you only have a few really strong examples it's ok--you *have strong examples.* The next biggest thing they want to guage is whether you'd be cool to work w & whether you're honest (don't lie--embellish if nec--like you did on your resume. You did embellish on it, right?)
12. All good designers have an ego. Notice I didnt say it was a problem.
13. All good designers take too much time to get it right and skew their hours to keep the budget in order.
14. Good designers dont always have time to get it right on their own (see 6.)

15. Some designers will be threatened by your work & your presence & will work to undermine you, usually by very subtle means that no one will notice but you, leaving you to wonder if it's real or just you (it's very likely real--see 12.)

16. Tolerating these types may be necessary in a tight job market. Do not gossip about it or even acknowledge it. Keep your head down and do *great work* as long as you can take it or have to, then graciously leave when you are able (see 9.)

17. If a bad situation comes to a head, *do not* bother your CD/AD w it. Confront the perp w good intentions & *do not* accuse him (it will *almost always* be a 'him'). Do this only in lieu of not being able to quit on healthy terms.

18. Great paid social media/PPC/SEO mgrs request a lot and never know what they're gonna get from you, and must put their complete faith in you. Be good to them. Do great work for them. Appreciate their needs.

19. If they request a change to your deliverable, do it. If they send it back twice, have a huddle or a meeting to set a clear agenda. If they continually nitpick, *politely & respectfully* tell them to stay in their fucking lane.
20. For the inexperienced designer,  most male design pros who are above you in pecking order are much harder to work for than female design pros.

21. As an experienced designer, female design pros will shit on you if you're a male, coddle you (to a point) if you're female. Female design pros have eaten more shit than you will ever know. It is what it is, and they expect you to deal.

22. Attention to detail is *almost* more critical than being great at design. You might just make it if you are the former and not the latter (but going into STEM wld probably be more rewarding if you can accept you have a low design ceiling).
23. Don't be afraid of change. In fact, if you dont live for change your skills and most importantly, your eye for what's good will erode. Never stop learning.

Read *a lot* of great fiction. Understand allegory, metaphor; text & archetypes; know colloquialism from colloquium; speak (or strive to understand as best you can) the language of writers--theyll help you become a great visual communicator (& stregthen your audiospatial skills).

25. Trust your gut-reaction and know when it is speaking from your sentiment. Sentiment and design rarely make good bedfellows (see 23.) Your gut knows what's good. Your sentiment is for your grandparents and election day.

26. The bigger the client, the less they will like bold changes (they know what butters their bread). If they aren't turning to you in crisis, incremental change may be the best (but have a bold idea ready, especially if it excites you, and know how to articulate it--see 24.)

27. Small accts: don't try to "wow them" w clever bs. They may be a breath away from just trying it on their own (see 1.). Get them talking, listen very carefully & take lots of notes (& do so over a beer if possible & not over the phone). They likely sleep even less than you do.

28. Grand scale design: ESPN branding. Every graphic, color, font-face, ticker, title, promo, sweeper, intro-outro, online/print/video (& even audio) asset is consistent, bc they strictly follow a style guide that must stretch to the moon & back. A truly remarkable achievement.

29. Who cares? Watch Fox sports on a random TV. You'll only know it's Fox when they tell you. ESPN branding is the golden arches of the sports world. You know it's them on your screen within 6 seconds by the (unbranded) screen bugs or white balance & movement of their crane cams.

30. It's all *by design.* Every frame, every pixel falls under the strictest of guidelines. Many don't follow suit because only a handful have the resources to pull it off (ESPN is a Disney subsidiary).

31. As a designer, someone once told you to notice great design work. Dont be intimidated by the great deliverables you see; rather, aspire to deliver the same impeccable quality to your clients & hold your work to the same standard. Create for where youre going not where you are

32. Most agency ppl (most any ppl) will not tell you if your work is good or not. It's up to you to find ppl who'll be honest w you--seek out criticism. But *only* do so *from ppl who know wtf they're talking about.* (ie not friends, not spouses, not randos).
33. Dribbble, Behance come to mind. Volunteer for your local AIGA, join Meetup groups. Listen and be discriminating. Even in professional circles there's still plenty of bad advice handed out.
34. In the end it's still all about your gut (See 25.)

35. Read "Finite and Infinite Games." In the book, Carse discusses successful art & design as having the ability to surprise. A good designer knows when this happens. This is when most agency ppl (and most any ppl) tell you something is in fact good (See 32.)

36. Likewise, this is when your saboteur will tell you it is not good, or will be indifferent, just to fuck w you (See 15.) *Never* show your work, especially not great work, to your saboteur 1st. Rmmbr they want to destroy you, especially when you wave a great idea in their face

Make lots of logos & wordmarks?
Find $50 & buy Trademarks and Symbols

@bantjes
Generative design
@zachlieberman 
Please respond/repost your favs
38. Testing: it isn't about being pretty. It's about what users respond to. Not every great deliverable will be visually dazzling. Let that shit go (See 25.)
39. Testing: Some of the bulliest Control creatives I've ever tried to knock down were unremarkable in every way other than their ability to garner tons of clicks & leads.

40. Testing: Hobby stores & insurance quote aggregator leads may respond to great copy or offers. Outdoor gear & crypto site leads may respond to visual assets. Some may respond to neither. Lost? Your client > Google here. What do they say? (See 26., 27.)
41. Designers who work at the same agency 3+ years will be more comfortable (& prob have better personal relationships).
42. Designers who work for the same agency â‰¤ 2.5 years earn more money.

43. CDs & Team leads: Dont give an intern--especially one w a great portfolio--your shit spreadsheet work, migrating email contacts & archiving junk bc you don't wanna do it. Even more so don't do it if the position is unpaid. This is their opportunity not yours.

44. Interns: you're there to learn & it *is* priceless. Dont bitch or think it's ok to be lazy bc you're not getting paid. (But if your employer is giving you junk all day, quit on good terms & go where you will not be taken advantage of--it's your opportunity not theirs).

45. If you suffer from ADHD (many designers do), distractions will eat away precious hours of productivity. Get a pair of noise-canceling headphones and find a quiet place where you can get lost in your imagination and create.
46. Dont respond to Slacks, dont answer unscheduled calls, dont check emails. Get what you need out of the way then deep dive. Put up a do not disturb sign if you have to.
That's *CVs.*
